Award.AwardTitle: Footprint formation and interpreting fossil dinosaur tracks
Award.AbstractNarration:
New Title:
Footprint formation and interpreting fossil dinosaur tracks

Non-technical Abstract
Dinosaur tracks offer unique evidence of the anatomy, behavior, and environment of long-extinct animals when they were alive. These tracks and trackways are recognized as unrivaled glimpses into dinosaur locomotion, recording aspects of gait, speed, limb posture, foot motion, and even social behavior. A single animal's tracks can vary dramatically depending on the firmness of the substrate and how deeply it sank with each step. This project aims to understand both the effects of substrate on locomotion and the origin of track diversity in the fossil record. 3-D movement of birds walking on different substrates will be measured using skeletal models animated using X-ray video. Computer simulations of track formation will reveal how tracks develop both at the surface and at different depths. These exciting new methods developed by the researchers for imaging, quantifying, and simulating locomotion through deformable substrates will provide an entirely new, volumetric perspective on the "birth" of a dinosaur track. Simulated bird tracks will then be compared to 200 million year old dinosaur tracks to help explain variation in shape and correct errors in previous interpretations. Results from this research will fundamentally change our perception and interpretation of dinosaur tracks by unlocking previously invisible motions and mechanisms.



Technical Abstract
Why are footprints shaped the way they are? How and why does a single animal produce a disparate array of tracks? The proposed project aims to continue a fruitful collaboration between Gatesy (paleontology, biomechanics, and functional anatomy) and Falkingham (computer science, geology, and paleontology). The PIs will explore the emergence of footprint morphology from the dynamic interplay between bipedal dinosaurs and deformable substrates. They seek to understand the origin and functional significance of Mesozoic track diversity by exploring disparate specimens in the historic Hitchcock Ichnology Collection at the Beneski Museum of Natural History at Amherst College. PIs will integrate living bird experiments (XROMM: X-ray Reconstruction of Moving Morphology) and substrate simulations (DEM: Discrete Element Method) to reveal important interactions among anatomy, motion, and sediment properties governing footprint formation. Volumetric DEM models of guineafowl tracks in varying substrates will serve as reference for interpreting and iteratively simulating specific specimens from the Connecticut Valley and Greenland. Results from this research will fundamentally change our perception and interpretation of dinosaur tracks by unlocking previously inaccessible foot/sediment dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award Title: Footprint formation and interpreting fossil dinosaur tracks

Federal Award ID: 1452119

PIs: Stephen Gatesy and Peter Falkingham

 

Intellectual merit:

The fossilized footprints of dinosaurs and other extinct species offer unique evidence about life on Earth in the distant past. Yet the ability of paleontologists to discover and document track has far outpaced their ability to understand them. Research funded by this award sought answers to fundamental questions about why footprints are shaped the way they are. Specifically, data from X-ray imaging of living birds making tracks, 3-D computer simulations of track formation, and actual fossils of Early Jurassic dinosaur tracks from the Connecticut Valley were integrated into a framework allowing footprints to be understood as dynamic records of animal-environment interaction, rather than static objects.

Key project findings include:1) A single species, or even single individual, can form a dramatic range of track shapes when walking through substrates of differing consistency. 2) So-called penetrative tracks, which form below the visible surface when animals sink into soft muds or dry sand, are exceedingly common worldwide and frequently go unrecognized. 3) Soft substrates can flow very unevenly around and over feet as they penetrate, creating track shapes that deviate substantially from foot shape. 4) The feet of modern birds follow a loop underground, entering and exiting along different paths. Fossil tracks show that dinosaurs responded similarly ~200 million years ago. Sampling depth and substrate-induced variation in loop shape can account for more than half of the apparent Connecticut Valley track diversity. 5) Virtual reality visualization tools are well-suited to exploring the complex particle movements and foot-particle interactions generated by computer simulations of track formation.

 

Broader impacts:

 The project provided interdisciplinary training to three graduate students and three undergraduate students. Close collaboration with computer scientists led to a new virtual reality application for data visualization (DinoTrackViewer) and two semesters of interdisciplinary teaching (CS137: Virtual Reality Design for Science) with David Laidlaw (Brown, Computer Science) and Fritz Drury (Rhode Island School of Design, Illustration). Findings were disseminated through seven journal publications, one book chapter, one field guide, and one commentary. Photographs and 3-D models of dinosaur track fossils have been made available as supplementary data. The PI?s and students presented over two dozen talks and posters at scientific conferences, participated in two workshops, gave several public seminars, and appeared in two documentaries. An estimated 2000-3000 guests visited the YURT virtual reality theater at Brown and experienced a demonstration of the DinoTrackViewer application in person. Finally, a permanent display was developed, constructed, and installed in the fossil track gallery of the Beneski Museum of Natural History at Amherst College, which houses the largest collection of fossil tracks in the world. An associated web page describing the NSF-funded research on track formation is maintained on the Beneski Museum site.
